treatments.name: Benzoyl Peroxide
treatments.description: Benzoyl peroxide is an antimicrobial agent that kills acne-causing bacteria and helps unclog pores.
treatments.usage: Apply a thin layer to affected areas once or twice daily. Start with lower concentrations (2.5%) to minimize irritation.
treatments.precautions: Start with lower concentrations and gradually increase. Use sunscreen as it can increase photosensitivity.

treatments.name: Salicylic Acid
treatments.description: A beta-hydroxy acid that exfoliates the skin and helps unclog pores by removing dead skin cells.
treatments.usage: Apply to affected areas 1-2 times daily. Available in concentrations from 0.5% to 2%.
treatments.precautions: Avoid contact with eyes. May increase sun sensitivity.

treatments.name: Retinoids (Tretinoin)
treatments.description: Vitamin A derivatives that promote cell turnover and prevent clogged pores. Prescription strength retinoids are highly effective.
treatments.usage: Apply a pea-sized amount to entire face every other night initially, then nightly as tolerated.
treatments.precautions: Use sunscreen daily. Start slowly to build tolerance. Avoid during pregnancy.

treatments.name: Antibiotics (Oral)
treatments.description: Oral antibiotics like doxycycline, minocycline, or erythromycin help reduce acne-causing bacteria and inflammation.
treatments.usage: Take as prescribed by dermatologist, typically for 3-6 months. Always complete the full course.
treatments.precautions: Take with food to reduce GI upset. Use sunscreen. Avoid long-term use.

treatments.name: Isotretinoin (Accutane)
treatments.description: A powerful oral retinoid reserved for severe, cystic acne that hasn't responded to other treatments.
treatments.usage: Prescribed by dermatologist with strict monitoring. Treatment typically lasts 4-6 months.
treatments.precautions: Requires pregnancy prevention program. Regular blood monitoring needed. Avoid vitamin A supplements.

treatments.name: Hormonal Therapy
treatments.description: Birth control pills or anti-androgen medications can help women with hormonal acne.
treatments.usage: Prescribed by healthcare provider. Effects may take 3-6 months to see improvement.
treatments.precautions: Not suitable for all women. Discuss medical history with provider.

treatments.name: Chemical Peels
treatments.description: Professional treatments using acids to exfoliate skin and improve acne and acne scarring.
treatments.usage: Performed by dermatologist or licensed aesthetician. Series of treatments typically needed.
treatments.precautions: Avoid sun exposure after treatment. Follow post-care instructions carefully.

treatments.name: Light Therapy
treatments.description: Blue light therapy targets acne-causing bacteria, while red light reduces inflammation.
treatments.usage: Professional treatments 2-3 times per week for several weeks.
treatments.precautions: Protect eyes during treatment. May not be suitable for all skin types.

morning.description: Use a mild, non-comedogenic cleanser to remove overnight buildup without over-drying.
morning.tips: Avoid harsh scrubbing. Use lukewarm water.

morning.description: Apply any prescribed topical treatments like benzoyl peroxide or retinoids.
Use a lightweight, non-comedogenic moisturizer to maintain skin barrier.
morning.tips: Even oily skin needs moisture. Look for oil-free formulas.

morning.description: Apply broad-spectrum sunscreen to prevent UV damage and post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.
morning.tips: Reapply every 2 hours. Choose non-comedogenic formulas.

evening.description: Remove makeup, sunscreen, and daily buildup with a gentle cleanser.
evening.tips: Double cleanse if wearing heavy makeup or sunscreen.

evening.description: Apply evening treatments like retinoids or other prescribed medications.
evening.tips: Start slowly with new treatments to build tolerance.

evening.description: Use a slightly richer moisturizer to repair and hydrate overnight.
evening.tips: Can use a heavier formula at night than during the day.

lifestyle_tips.description: Some studies suggest dairy and high-sugar foods may worsen acne in some individuals.
Dirty pillowcases can harbor bacteria and oils that may contribute to acne.
Chronic stress can worsen acne by increasing hormone production and inflammation.
Remove sweat and bacteria promptly after exercise to prevent clogged pores.
Hands carry bacteria and oils that can worsen acne when transferred to the face.

when_to_see_dermatologist: Over-the-counter treatments haven't worked after 6-8 weeks
Acne is affecting self-esteem or quality of life
You're experiencing side effects from treatments
Acne suddenly worsens or changes pattern

myths_and_facts.myth: Acne is caused by poor hygiene
myths_and_facts.fact: Acne is primarily caused by hormones, genetics, and bacteria. Over-washing can actually worsen acne.
While sun may temporarily dry out acne, it can worsen it long-term and cause premature aging.

myths_and_facts.myth: Popping pimples helps them heal faster
myths_and_facts.fact: Popping pimples can push bacteria deeper, cause scarring, and spread infection.
Adult acne is common, especially in women due to hormonal fluctuations.
Non-comedogenic makeup doesn't cause acne. The key is proper removal and choosing the right products.
